caption.title: Synthesis of N-(5-methylthiazol-2-yl)−3-oxobutanamide (3).
caption.p: To a solution of 5-methylthiazol-2-amine (1) (0.5 g; 4.39 mmol) in xylene (10 ml) was added 2, 2-dimethyl-4H-1, 3-dioxin-4-one (2) (685 mg; 4.83 mmol). Galkin et al., 2010a. The mixture was stirred for 12 hr at 135°C, then cooled to room temperature. The solution was filtered and washed with petroleum ether, after filtration, the solid was used directly without purification (3) (0.73 g; 3.69 mmol, 84%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.95 (s, 1H), 7.13 (s, 1H), 3.66 (s, 2H), 2.34 (s, 3H), 2.19 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 202.68, 165.26, 156.30, 135.18, 126.70, 51.22, 30.70, 11.53; HRMS (m/z): [M+H]+ calculated for C8H11N2O2S, 199.0530; found, 199.0548.

fn.p: Footnotes not linked to content within the table text are usually to define abbreviations. For example:
WT, wild type.

Footnotes can be used to highlight properties of data reported in a table such as statistical significance. They are separate from the table caption and appear afterwards. They are hyperlinked to allow easy navigation. Footnotes in tables use the same standard set of symbols used for authors footnotes (Paciência, 2019).
Atoms: Cα, N, C, O.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: ... Here is another example of coloured text.

The function of the Discussion is to interpret your results in light of what was already known about the subject of the investigation, and to explain our new understanding of the problem after taking your results into consideration (R Development Core Team, 2017; Cantaut-Belarif et al., 2020; Galkin et al., 2010b; Box 1). The Discussion will always connect to the Introduction by way of the question(s) or hypotheses you posed and the literature you cited, but it does not simply repeat or rearrange the Introduction (Supplementary file 1). Instead, it tells how your study has moved us forward from the place you left us at the end of the Introduction as in R Development Core Team, 2017; Box 1—figure 1.

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: Sequencing data have been deposited in GEO under accession code GSE143275 (Hao et al., 2020). We also used some data from Dryad (Kok et al., 2015). All other data generated or analysed during this study are included in the manuscript and supporting files. MATLAB scripts used to generate Figures 1-3 are available at GitHub (copy archived at Cantaut-Belarif et al., 2020).

body.p: This is an eLife assessment, which is a summary of the peer reviews provided by the BRE. It will only contain one or more paragraphs, no figures, tables or videos. It might say something like, "with respect to blah blah, this study is noteworthy backed up by data that is compelling, however the model design for blah is flawed and the evidence incomplete.

This paper combines two complementary approaches, translating ribosome affinity purification (TRAP) and ribosome profiling, to provide the first quantitative insight into the impact of PrPSc on cell type-specific translation. Surprisingly few translational changes were detected in neurons. In contrast, substantial alterations to translation were evident in astrocytes and microglia prior to manifestation of prion disease features, suggesting that aberrant translation in these cell types may be a primary driver of neurodegeneration.
The reviewers have discussed the reviews with one another and the Reviewing Editor has drafted this decision to help you prepare a revised submission.

You need to make sure the XML structure you create works on the display of the PMC platform and also that there is enough information contained within the tagging to generate a typeset PDF from the XML with no additional information provided. See Review image 1., Review table 1 and Review video 1.

Each reviewer's report is included as a separate sub-article. This will usually mean three reviews, though more or fewer are permitted. Reviews may be published anonymously.
Review assets are ordered sequentially across all the separate reviews, so the second image will be called Review image 2 regardless of which reviews it appears in.

body.p: Each reviewer's report is included as a separate sub-article. This will usually mean three reviews, though more or fewer are permitted. Reviews may be published anonymously.
The public review reached by consensus.
The public review containing comments from all reviewers.
Recommendations for edits to the initial preprint, based on the reviewers' comments.

contrib-group.on-behalf-of: on behalf of whoever finds this interesting

body.p: We thank the reviewers for the positive assessment of our work and their insightful remarks. Please find below a point-by-point response to each comment.

disp-quote.p: Scheckel et al. report a large dataset on cell type-specific translational profiling of PrD-associated molecular alterations in a mouse model thorough RiboTRAP and ribosome profiling approaches. They report a more severe alteration in the translatome specifically in astrocyte and microglia as compared to neuronal populations. This highlights that changes in these two cell classes might have a predominant role in the pathology of PrD.

Data and the methods are presented such that they can be reproduced. The data analysis section of the manuscript could be further elaborated. In particular, it could be clarified which/how comparisons with existing dataset have been performed. Statistical analysis description is sometimes missing (e.g. Figure 6E, not clear what the stars on top of the bars stands for, which test was performed and the significance). Moreover, the section of the Materials and methods regarding the western blots presented in Figure 6 appear to be missing.

body.p: Figure 6E shows the output (log2 fold change) of DESeq2. Genes with a Benjamini-Hochberg adjusted p value < 0.05 (also derived from DESeq2) are marked with an asterisk. We have added this information to the legend, as well as methods regarding western blots.

disp-quote.p: The reviewers have discussed the reviews with one another and the Reviewing Editor has drafted this decision to help you prepare a revised submission.

You need to make sure the XML structure you create works on the display of the PMC platform and also that there is enough information contained within the tagging to generate a typeset PDF from the XML with no additional information provided.

body.p: In response to this comment, we validated the XML against the DTD (JATS 1) each time we made an update. We also regularly used the PMC validator to check our decisions against display on the PMC site, see Author response image 1., Author response video 1 and Author response table 1.

caption.p: Single figure: The header of an eLife article example on the HTML page.
Author response table

caption.title: Caption and/or a title is required for all author response assets.

body.p: However, some decisions required some communication with PMC to discuss whether any of our updates could be accomodated by them - during this review we aimed to reduce the complexity of the XML structure and remove all formatting and bioler plate text required for a PDF display format. We also produced buisness rules {Insert table} order to produce rules for the production systems and the website to follow. These buisness rules also informed the basis for a set of Schematron rules for our references.
